description: The Certified Cloud Security Professional (CCSP) is a credential that is going to be relevant especially for people who want to focus on the knowledge areas of architectural concepts and design requirements, cloud data security, cloud platform and infrastructure security, cloud application security, and compliance concerns in a traditional standard enterprise environment. As powerful as cloud computing is for the organization, understanding its information security risks and mitigation strategies are critical. Legacy approaches are inadequate, and organizations need competent, experienced professionals equipped with the right cloud security knowledge and skills to be successful. The CCSP certification is for IT professionals with a minimum of five years of cumulative IT experience with backgrounds and exposure to cloud related services.
name: Certified Cloud Security Professional (UPDATED 2016)
subtitle: CCSP

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam give a general overview on the CCSP exam and what to expect in this series. Covers topics such as architectural concepts and design elements, cloud data security, cloud platform and infrastructure security, cloud application security, operational aspects of the cloud--physically and logically, and legal and compliance concerns.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.187 --> 00:00:08.818
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.818 --> 00:00:12.951
In this segment, we're going to give you
a brief overview of our upcoming series on

3
00:00:12.951 --> 00:00:15.266
the Certified Cloud Security Professional.

4
00:00:15.266 --> 00:00:18.969
Now, and joining me in the studio today to
help us out with that is our good friend,

5
00:00:18.969 --> 00:00:21.330
Adam, who will be joining
us in the series.

6
00:00:21.330 --> 00:00:23.840
Adam, can you give us a quick overview of

7
00:00:23.840 --> 00:00:26.030
what we should expect
from our upcoming series.

8
00:00:26.030 --> 00:00:26.550
>> Absolutely.

9
00:00:26.550 --> 00:00:30.740
So the CCSP is going to be
a credential that is going to be

10
00:00:30.740 --> 00:00:33.620
relevant to lots of people
in the organization, or

11
00:00:33.620 --> 00:00:36.680
in a traditional standard
enterprise organization today.

12
00:00:36.680 --> 00:00:40.350
But especially for people that wanna focus
on the following domains and knowledge.

13
00:00:40.350 --> 00:00:44.150
Let's probably first talk about makes up
the CCSP from a knowledge perspective.

14
00:00:44.150 --> 00:00:45.020
And then we'll talk for

15
00:00:45.020 --> 00:00:48.020
just a minute about the relevant
experience that somebody may need.

16
00:00:48.020 --> 00:00:51.030
So we're gonna look at six domains,
or six areas of knowledge over all.

17
00:00:51.030 --> 00:00:53.200
We're going to be talking about
architectural concepts and

18
00:00:53.200 --> 00:00:54.120
design requirements.

19
00:00:54.120 --> 00:00:56.580
So what does it take to really
understand how to build and

20
00:00:56.580 --> 00:00:59.370
architect the cloud both logically and
physically?

21
00:00:59.370 --> 00:01:00.730
Cloud data security.

22
00:01:00.730 --> 00:01:02.920
How do we secure the data
that's in the cloud?

23
00:01:02.920 --> 00:01:05.060
Cloud platform and
infrastructure security.

24
00:01:05.060 --> 00:01:08.040
How do we secure the underlying
infrastructure that makes the cloud

25
00:01:08.040 --> 00:01:08.610
possible?

26
00:01:08.610 --> 00:01:12.860
The hosts and the infrastructure that
we're going to run the cloud through,

27
00:01:12.860 --> 00:01:15.650
the networks, the storage,
all of that kind of stuff.

28
00:01:15.650 --> 00:01:18.520
Cloud applications security,
how do we secure the application so

29
00:01:18.520 --> 00:01:21.860
the workloads that run on top
of the host infrastructure?

30
00:01:21.860 --> 00:01:24.490
How do we deal with operational
aspects of the Cloud, so

31
00:01:24.490 --> 00:01:27.330
what does it mean to physically and
logically design the Cloud?

32
00:01:27.330 --> 00:01:30.760
How do we physically and logically
implement cloud infrastructure, and

33
00:01:30.760 --> 00:01:32.982
how do we manage it from
a security standpoint?

34
00:01:32.982 --> 00:01:36.631
And ultimately, of course, no complete
conversation there at all around those

35
00:01:36.631 --> 00:01:40.857
five things unless we wrap all that with
the idea of legal and compliance concerns.

36
00:01:40.857 --> 00:01:44.287
How do we operate effectively in
different jurisdictional areas?

37
00:01:44.287 --> 00:01:48.877
How as CCSPs are we aware of the rules,
in other words, we must align with

38
00:01:48.877 --> 00:01:52.877
from the GRC, a Governance Risk Compliance
perspective, with regards to the Cloud?

39
00:01:53.880 --> 00:01:57.150
Now, Adam who is the intended audience for
this specific series?

40
00:01:57.150 --> 00:01:59.100
>> So when we think, hello [LAUGH].

41
00:01:59.100 --> 00:02:03.300
When we think about the intended audience
for the cloud, we think about an IT

42
00:02:03.300 --> 00:02:06.810
professional first and foremost,
as we often start out talking about.

43
00:02:06.810 --> 00:02:10.070
In this case, an IT professional that
has some background, some experience,

44
00:02:10.070 --> 00:02:13.390
some exposure to cloud and
cloud related activities.

45
00:02:13.390 --> 00:02:16.400
They may work for a CSP,
a cloud service provider.

46
00:02:16.400 --> 00:02:19.830
They may work for an organization that
wants to go into the cloud business on

47
00:02:19.830 --> 00:02:24.150
their own running on prem private
cloud within the organization.

48
00:02:24.150 --> 00:02:27.550
IT in other words becomes the cloud
provider to the business, but

49
00:02:27.550 --> 00:02:29.030
it's all done internally.

50
00:02:29.030 --> 00:02:33.040
We may work for an organization that
is pondering a move to the cloud.

51
00:02:33.040 --> 00:02:36.460
Or we may be a consultant that is going
to be asked to consult and work for

52
00:02:36.460 --> 00:02:39.260
various organizations that
are going to be in the cloud

53
00:02:39.260 --> 00:02:41.880
at various stages of their development and
their use of the cloud.

54
00:02:41.880 --> 00:02:45.580
In order to be successful, according to
(ISC) squared, the CCSP candidate must

55
00:02:45.580 --> 00:02:50.990
have a minimum of five years of cumulative
paid full time IT experience over all,

56
00:02:50.990 --> 00:02:54.140
which most people will be
able to certainly provide and

57
00:02:54.140 --> 00:02:57.100
to offer evidence of these days.

58
00:02:57.100 --> 00:03:01.575
And of that five years, three years
must be in information security overall,

59
00:03:01.575 --> 00:03:04.985
one year or one focal year overall,

60
00:03:04.985 --> 00:03:07.815
in other words one sixth of the,
I'm sorry not one sixth, one fifth.

61
00:03:07.815 --> 00:03:09.345
Let me do the math correctly,

62
00:03:09.345 --> 00:03:12.830
one fifth of the overall amount of time we
need should be in a cloud focused domain.

63
00:03:12.830 --> 00:03:17.067
So one of the of the six domains that
i just mentioned to you, architecture,

64
00:03:17.067 --> 00:03:23.174
compliance, oversight in regards to cloud
management, operationally, architecture,

65
00:03:23.174 --> 00:03:26.782
et cetera, have one year of provable
experience in one of those domains.

66
00:03:26.782 --> 00:03:30.322
And then you're able to essentially
qualify to sit for the exam.

67
00:03:30.322 --> 00:03:30.842
>> Awesome.
Well,

68
00:03:30.842 --> 00:03:35.082
you talk about an exam, obviously there's
a certification that goes along with this.

69
00:03:35.082 --> 00:03:37.610
Adam, can you tell us a little
bit about that itself?

70
00:03:37.610 --> 00:03:41.070
>> So the certification itself, like many
of the exams that (ISC) squared has in

71
00:03:41.070 --> 00:03:44.330
market, all of them these days,
will be delivered computerized.

72
00:03:44.330 --> 00:03:46.330
So you'll be able to go out
to a testing center and

73
00:03:46.330 --> 00:03:48.650
take that exam when you've studied for
it and are ready.

74
00:03:48.650 --> 00:03:49.765
The exam will be timed.

75
00:03:49.765 --> 00:03:50.880
You'll have a certain amount of time.

76
00:03:50.880 --> 00:03:53.830
There will be a certain number of
questions associated with the exam,

77
00:03:53.830 --> 00:03:55.810
a pretty standard format in that respect.

78
00:03:55.810 --> 00:03:59.530
Multiple choice exam format
standardized today, so

79
00:03:59.530 --> 00:04:01.970
there may be test questions
that will be scenario based.

80
00:04:01.970 --> 00:04:04.485
They may be questions that will
be traditional multiple choice.

81
00:04:04.485 --> 00:04:07.625
There will be questions that may
be mix and match, drag and drop.

82
00:04:07.625 --> 00:04:11.275
Pretty standard exam format that we're
used to seeing in multiple vendor

83
00:04:11.275 --> 00:04:14.095
arenas today with regard to
how they will offer testing.

84
00:04:14.095 --> 00:04:18.147
The one thing that's interesting here,
is that (ISC) squared has partnered with

85
00:04:18.147 --> 00:04:22.987
the CSA, the Cloud Security Alliance,
which is an international trade group

86
00:04:22.987 --> 00:04:27.267
that is formed from some of the big
vendors in the cloud industry along with

87
00:04:27.267 --> 00:04:31.417
a lot of other players in the cloud
industry, focused on information security.

88
00:04:31.417 --> 00:04:34.967
And they are going to be able to,
because of this partnership,

89
00:04:34.967 --> 00:04:37.910
access the knowledge base the cloud
security alliance has developed.

90
00:04:37.910 --> 00:04:40.420
We'll talk about this in upcoming
episodes when you come in and

91
00:04:40.420 --> 00:04:42.150
start watching our material.

92
00:04:42.150 --> 00:04:45.140
But the interesting part here with regards
to the exam is that the Cloud Security

93
00:04:45.140 --> 00:04:49.210
Alliance has their own certification
on the market, the CCSK certificate.

94
00:04:49.210 --> 00:04:50.415
If you study for and

95
00:04:50.415 --> 00:04:55.005
achieve the CCSK Certificate from the CSA,
that actually is able

96
00:04:55.005 --> 00:04:59.315
to act as the one year of experience in
the cloud that (ISC) squared requires and

97
00:04:59.315 --> 00:05:02.815
you don't have to provide that one year of
documented experience through your resume.

98
00:05:02.815 --> 00:05:06.865
You simply can show that you
have that CCSK certification and

99
00:05:06.865 --> 00:05:08.920
then you're able to qualify for
and sit for the exam.

100
00:05:08.920 --> 00:05:10.055
I can do that as well.

101
00:05:10.055 --> 00:05:11.465
>> Excellent information Adam.

102
00:05:11.465 --> 00:05:14.020
We thank you for
explaining these things to us.

103
00:05:14.020 --> 00:05:17.806
And if it sounds like something that might
be interesting or necessary for you,

104
00:05:17.806 --> 00:05:20.476
we look forward to seeing you
in the upcoming episodes.

105
00:05:20.476 --> 00:05:26.274
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam take you through the foundational concepts for cloud computing. Here they will take you through some common cloud vernacular and definitions. Also they describe the consequences of implementing a cloud solution from a security perspective.
episodes.title: Cloud Computing Concepts

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue building the foundation knowledge and concepts for cloud computing. Here they dive into defining the service models such as IaaS, SaaS, and PaaS. They also describe the different deployment models like Private Cloud, Public Cloud, Hybrid Cloud, and Community Cloud.
episodes.title: Describe Cloud Reference Architecture

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam move forward with their exposition on fundamental cloud services concepts and definitions. Here they take a look at the many roles that cloud admins and architects. This includes cloud customer, cloud administrator, cloud developer, and cloud service managers etc.
episodes.title: Describe Cloud Reference Architecture Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam take you through the TCI Reference Architecture matrix which will show the ways and areas that we need to address as an entity that is considering or utilizing cloud services and how we can secure them.
episodes.title: Cloud Security Concepts

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam talk about the common risks inherent to cloud environments. They walk you through areas of risk pertaining to the hypervisors, both type-I and type-II, as well as risks that are present with IaaS, Saas, and PaaS. They also discuss the importance of physical security.
episodes.title: Cloud Security Concepts Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam spend time taking a look at the top 10 Application security risks; describing them one by one. They also explain the Cloud Data Security Life Cycle which helps us understand the phases that our data abides in at any given time. Finally they discuss Service Level Agreements(SLA) from a security and risk perspective, which is basically our contract of service with our cloud provider.
episodes.title: Secure Cloud Design Principles

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam take a closer look at the Cloud Security Data Life Cycle phases. They explain what it takes to keep data secure at each one of these phases from securely storing to making sure that destroyed data is unrecoverable. They also talk about the idea of how secure a cloud solution is.
episodes.title: Cloud Data Security

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam explain some considerations that need to be addressed when designing and implementing Cloud data storage architectures. They start by looking at storage locations and access mechanisms like mandatory and discretionary access controls. Finally they discuss the differences between object and block/volume storage.
episodes.title: Cloud Data Storage Architectures

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam begin looking at designing and applying cloud data security strategies. They start by exploring the many threats to data that can be encountered like, DDOS, unauthorized access, data corruption, and internal malfeasance. Then they go over the available technologies to help mitigate those threats, specifically exploring encryption.
episodes.title: Cloud Data Security Strategies

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue their discussion on cloud data security strategies, jumping right back in with more about encryption implementations. Next they explore the different systems of encryption key management; describing the benefits of each. They discuss where keys should be stored and the importance of backups in case of key loss.
episodes.title: Cloud Data Security Strategies Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam finish their discussion on cloud data security strategies, jumping right back in with more about encryption implementations. Here, they take you through a myriad of security technologies like masking and obfuscation. They also explain the process of Tokenization. Finally they look at emerging technologies like bit splitting and homomorphic encryption.
episodes.title: Cloud Data Security Strategies Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam help you understand and implement Data Discovery and Classification techniques. They begin by explaining what Data Discovery is and how it is done through data labeling and content analysis. Then they tackle Data Classification to prioritize by sensitivity and the challenges of adding protections and even re-evaluation and re-classification.
episodes.title: Cloud Data Discovery and Classification

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam take you through designing and implementing relevant jurisdictional data protections for personally identifiable information. They begin by defining common privacy terms like Data Subject, Controller, and Processor. They also examine the idea of legal constraints and considerations that must be accounted for when working with personal data. Finally they explore the discovery, classification, and control of personal data.
episodes.title: Designing Appropriate Data Protection

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam take a look at more data management concepts and practices. They start by exploring data rights management, then segueing into data retention, deletion, and archiving policies. Then they discuss auditability, traceability, and accountability of data events.
episodes.title: Data Rights Mgmt Retention and Data Events

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam walk you through the common cloud infrastructure components to help you better understand each from a cloud security perspective. They discuss the physical environment, the management plane, network components, and virtualization all the while giving insight on how to implement security to each.
episodes.title: Cloud Infrastructure Components

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam describe the importance of risk assessment with regards to Cloud infrastructure. They look at what risks could potentially impact a cloud infrastructure as well as virtualization specific risks. They then describe counter measures and mitigation strategies to protect our cloud infrastructure environments.
episodes.title: Cloud Infrastructure Risks

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam discuss the designing and planning of security controls. They start by looking at controlling the physical environment, including the building, support structures, and the physical devices themselves. Then they move on to looking at security control measures for the virtualization and communications systems.
episodes.title: Design and Plan Security Controls

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue discussing possible security controls for your cloud infrastructure. They pick up by looking at controlling access through Identity, Authentication, and Authorization systems. Then they talk about Auditing as security which helps us verify that our security measures are being effective. This also includes the cloud-specific considerations that will need to be addressed.
episodes.title: Design and Plan Security Controls Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam being their discussion of Disaster Recovery(DR) and Business Continuity management. They begin by pointedly defining what exactly DR and Business Continuity are so that we can effectively plan and implement them. They they look at the risks that could lead to implementing BCDR plans. They also cover the 3 ways that a Cloud solution can be leveraged for BCDR.
episodes.title: Disaster, Recovery, and Business Continuity

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam finish their dissertation on Disaster Recovery and Business Continuity. Here they pick back up by exploring the strategies that can be implemented toward forming a BCDR plan. Then they discuss the importance of testing the plan to discover possible issues and verify that the BCDR plan will actually work when needed.
episodes.title: Disaster, Recovery and Business Continuity Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam explore the necessity of building secure applications. They begin the discussion by looking at cloud development of both RESTful and SOAP apps and common pitfalls to avoid. They also discuss the SDLC or Software Development Life-Cycle. Finally they cover common API vulnerabilities, cloud-specific risks, and threat modeling.
episodes.title: Cloud Application Security and the SDLC

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam discuss the necessity of using software that has been verified as secure and then look at Identity and Access Management(IAM) solutions. They explain secure software by way of looking at approved APIs, supply-chain management, and open-source/community software. They describe IAM design by discussing Federated IDs, ID providers, Single Sign-On(SSO), and the use of multi-factor authentication.
episodes.title: Identity and Access Management Solutions

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam explain the specifics of Cloud based software assurance and validation as well as cloud application architectures. They begin by looking at supplemental security devices and cryptographic systems that developers will need to pass through and comply with. They discuss securing apps through sandboxing and app virtualization. Finally, they begin looking at security verification of the apps through testing.
episodes.title: Cloud Software Assurance and Validation

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue their talk on cloud software assurance and validation; picking back up with app security testing practices. Here they take you through some of the common testing procedures like DAST, SAST, and Pen Testing. They also look at the OWASP testing guide and ISO
episodes.title: Cloud Software Assurance and Validation Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam discuss the ways in which we can implement security from the onset of implementation of our physical infrastructure. They start by exploring the secure-by-design physical components that can/should be used in the build, including TPM, secure storage controllers, and network controllers. Finally they go over some of the baked-in security features of the virtualization management tools.
episodes.title: Implement and Build Physical Infrastructure

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam talk about what it takes to run your physical infrastructure securely. They go over physical access security measures like secure KVMs. They also talk more about secure network configurations by using VLANs, TLS, DNS Sec, and firewalls. Finally they discuss physical segregation for stand-alone hosts and the availability of clustered hosts through DRS, Dynamic Optimization, and High Availability.
episodes.title: Running Physical Infrastructure

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam jump into the topic of managing a physical infrastructure. Here they begin by managing and monitoring access, patches/updates, and performance through logs and monitoring interfaces. Then they look at the implementation of network security controls like firewalls, IDS/IPS, and honeypots. Finally they look at log aggregation software for ease of management.
episodes.title: Managing Physical Infrastructure

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam begin their discussion on ensuring compliance to the policies for your systems. They start by discussing the CCSP's role as the voice for security implementation throughout the systems. Then they talk about the necessity for Configuration Management and Change Management to keep the systems running at the prescribed benchmarks and any deviation is documented and approved.
episodes.title: Ensure Compliance

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam finish their conversation on ensuring Compliance using regulations/controls through different management systems. Here they cover the concepts and need for incident/problem management, release management and deployment management. They also cover Service Level management, availability management, and Capacity Management.
episodes.title: Ensure Compliance Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam explore the planning process for data center design. They start by looking at figuring out what factors will effect the build of our data-centers. They then dive into the logical design which will affect our physical design as well as other physical design considerations such as cooling and cable management.
episodes.title: Planning Data Center Design

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam discuss the process and concepts of Risk Assessment. They start by defining risk which leads them to looking at defined ways of framing risk. They then move into risk assessment by explaining qualitative vs. quantitative risk, as well as cost benefit analysis which will help determine your which strategy will be taken, be that Acceptance, Avoidance, Transference, and/or Mitigation.
episodes.title: Risk Assessment

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam take you through the process of collecting and preserving of evidence in the case of a data breach incident. They explain the proper methods of collecting data and then detail the proper way that evidence should be handled. They also explore the different parties and stakeholders that need to be notified and informed during this time.
episodes.title: Collection and Preservation of Digital Evidence

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam begin their discussion on legal compliance, specifically looking at legal requirements and considerations unique to Cloud environments. They look at international legislation conflicts and legal controls that may apply to your cloud systems. They also talk about eDiscovery and forensic requirements that can apply if investigation is engaged.
episodes.title: Legal Requirements and Privacy

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam finish their talk on legal requirements and privacy. Here they begin by examining Personal Identity information and privacy concerns with regards to that. They define key terms that will help PII be properly managed. Finally they look at jurisdictional issues that may arise due to the global nature of much of cloud-based data.
episodes.title: Legal Requirements and Privacy Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam examine the audit process for cloud-based systems. They start by differentiating between internal and external audits. Then they talk about assurance challenges of Cloud systems. Finally, they walk you through the different types of audit reports, restrictions, and gap analysis.
episodes.title: Cloud Audit Processes

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue their examination of audit processes in cloud-based systems. Here they start by going through what it takes to develop an audit plan using standards as a guide. They also discuss Policies that will be used to make sure that compliance standards are stated and met. They also look at the impact of the distributed IT model.
episodes.title: Cloud Audit Processes Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam contemplate the implications of Risk Management with regards to the Cloud. They assess the provider's risk and risk management as well as risk mitigation techniques. Then they go over many risk frameworks and metrics. Finally they discuss outsourcing and contract understanding/management.
episodes.title: Risk Management and Outsourcing
